title.en: Learning from the History of Philosophy

faculty.address:
Tartu linn, 
Tartu linn, Tartumaa 
EST

course_main_structural_unit.address:
Jakobi 2, III korrus, ruumid 315, 319-326, 328, 336-337
51005 Tartu linn, 
Tartu linn, Tartumaa 
EST

description.en: Kursus annab ülevaate mõnedest kanoonilistest ja mittekanoonilistest filosoofia ajaloo tekstidest alates Antiik-Kreekast kuni tänapäevani. Keskendutakse nende tekstide mõistmiseks, tõlgendamiseks ja nende üle reflekteerimiseks vajalike oskuste arendamisele.
description.et: The course is a survey of some of the canonical and non-canonical texts in the history of philosophy from ancient Greek to contemporary philosophy. The focus is on developing relevant skills for understanding, interpreting, and reflecting on these texts.

objectives.en: Kursus pakub intensiivse sissejuhatuse olulistesse tekstidesse filosoofia ajaloos (sealhulgas mõningatesse peamistesse kontseptsioonidesse ja aruteludesse, mille osa need tekstid olid) ning arendab üliõpilaste tekstianalüüsi oskusi nagu tekstiliste tõendite efektiivne ja vastutustundlik kasutamine, samal ajal ajaloolise kontekstiga arvestamine; võime võrrelda ja hinnata teksti alternatiivseid tõlgendusi, rakendades põhilisi hermeneutilisi põhimõtteid (näiteks heatahtlikkuse põhimõte). Samuti õpetab see üliõpilasi transponeerima ajaloolistes tekstides esitatud argumente ja väiteid teistesse uurimisvaldkondadesse.
objectives.et: This course provides an intensive introduction to key texts in the history of philosophy (including some of the key concepts and debates those texts were a part of), and develops students' skills in textual analysis: the use of textual evidence effectively and responsibly while remaining sensitive to the historical context; the ability to compare and evaluate alternative interpretations of a text by applying basic hermeneutic principles (e.g. the principle of charity). It also teaches students to transpose the arguments and claims set forth in historical texts to other domains of inquiry.

learning_outcomes.en: On a successful completion of the course, the student has:

* acquired abilities that allow the student to work independently with historical texts, such as the ability to reconstruct the views and arguments found in the text, to critically evaluate competing interpretations while being sensitive to historical context;
learning_outcomes.et: * omandanud oskused, mis võimaldavad tal iseseisvalt töötada ajalooliste tekstidega, näiteks oskused rekonstrueerida tekstis sisalduvaid vaateid ja argumente, kriitiliselt hinnata konkureerivaid tõlgendusi, olles samas tundlik ajaloolise konteksti suhtes;

learning_outcomes.en: * gained a thorough understanding of some of the key concepts, theories, and central disputes in the history of philosophy;
learning_outcomes.et: * sügavuti mõistnud mõningaid filosoofia ajaloo põhimõisteid, teooriaid ja keskseid debatte;

learning_outcomes.en: * learned the skills required for writing a scholarly philosophical text and for expressing their views clearly and coherently in oral discussions.
learning_outcomes.et: * omandanud oskused, mis on vajalikud akadeemilise filosoofilise teksti kirjutamiseks ning oma seisukohtade selgeks ja sidusaks väljendamiseks suulises arutelus.

independent_work.et:
* Reading and reflecting on the required material for each class. 
* Writing essays that include quotations from the required texts.

description.et:
Regular attendance and active participation in seminar discussions and Moodle assignments demonstrate the student's ability to engage with texts and one another critically. 
(differentiated, 25%)

3 essay drafts that are reviewed among the peers, demonstrating a critical ability to recognise key arguments put forth by the authors.
 (non-differentiated, 5% x 3 = 15%)

3 written essays that are developed from earlier drafts that are reviewed by fellow students.
(differentiated, 20% x 3 = 60%)

grade_preconditions.et:
Final grade is cumulative (based on assessment methods listed in SIS). 
The student must earn at least 51% for the course (corresponding to E) to get a positive grade.
A = 90-100%
B = 80-89%
C = 70-79%
D = 60-69%
E = 50-59%
F = less than 50%

grade_evaluation.et:
* Regular attendance and active participation in seminar discussions - 25% of the final grade.
* 3 peer-reviewed essay drafts - 15% of the final grade. 
* 3 written essays developed from earlier drafts - 60% of the final grade.
Final grade is cumulative (based on assessment methods listed in SIS). To earn a positive grade, the student must earn the minimum grade of 51% (E).

debt_elimination.et: Late submissions are not accepted. If the student needs an extension, they must contact the instructor before the deadline.

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

resources.mandatory_materials:
* Aristotle, Nicomachean Ethics
* John Locke, Two Treatises of Government
* Hannah Arendt, The Human Condition

description.et:
Seminars twice a week.

Topics:
Week 1: Introduction
Week 2: Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics 
Week 3: Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics 
Week 4: Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics 
Week 5: Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics 
Week 6: Locke's Two Treatises of Government 
Week 7: Locke's Two Treatises of Government 
Week 8: Locke's Two Treatises of Government 
Week 9: Locke's Two Treatises of Government 
Week 10: Arendt's The Human Condition 
Week 11: Arendt's The Human Condition 
Week 12: Arendt's The Human Condition 
Week 13: Arendt's The Human Condition  
Week 14: Comparing analysis

audience.et: Philosophy MA students, all other MA and PhD students, visiting students at all levels
